abstract.t: This document presents a base set of Object types and Verbs for use with Activity Streams.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document presents a base set of object types and verbs for use with Activity Streams.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: This specification allows the use of IRIs [RFC3987]. Every URI [RFC3986] is also an IRI, so a URI MAY be used wherever an IRI is named. When an IRI that is not also a URI is given for dereferencing, it MUST be mapped to a URI using the steps in Section 3.1 of [RFC3987]. When an IRI is serving as an identifier, it MUST NOT be so mapped.

texttable.c: Indicates that that the actor has accepted the object. For instance, a person accepting an award, or accepting an assignment.
Indicates that the actor has gained access to the object.
Indicates that the actor has acknowledged the object. This effectively signals that the actor is aware of the objects existence.
Indicates that the actor has added the object to the target. For instance, adding a photo to an album.
Indicates that the actor agrees with the object.
Indicates that the actor has appended the object to the target. For instance, a person appending a new record to a database.
Indicates that the actor has approved the object. For instance, a manager might approve a travel request.
Indicates that the actor has archived the object.
Indicates that the actor has assigned the object to the target.
Indicates that the actor is currently located at the object. For instance, a person being at a specific physical location.
Indicates that the actor has attached the object to the target. For instance, a person attaching a file to a wiki page or an email.
Indicates that the actor has attended the object. For instance, a person attending a meeting.
Indicates that the actor has authored the object. Note that this is a more specific form of the verb "create".

Indicates that the actor has authorized the object. If a target is specified, it means that the authorization is specifically in regards to the target. For instance, a service can authorize a person to access a given application; in which case the actor is the service, the object is the person, and the target is the application. In contrast, a person can authorize a request; in which case the actor is the person and the object is the request and there might be no explicit target.

Indicates that the actor has borrowed the object. If a target is specified, it identifies the entity from which the object was borrowed. For instance, if a person borrows a book from a library, the person is the actor, the book is the object and the library is the target.
Indicates that the actor has built the object. For example, if a person builds a model or compiles code.
Indicates that the actor has canceled the object. For instance, canceling a calendar event.
Indicates that the actor has closed the object.
Indicates that the actor has completed the object.
Indicates that the actor has confirmed or agrees with the object. For instance, a software developer might confirm an issue reported against a product.

Indicates that the actor has consumed the object. The specific meaning is dependent largely on the object's type. For instance, an actor may "consume" an audio object, indicating that the actor has listened to it; or an actor may "consume" a book, indicating that the book has been read. As such, the "consume" verb is a more generic form of other more specific verbs such as "read" and "play".
Indicates that the actor has checked-in to the object. For instance, a person checking-in to a Place.
Indicates that the actor has closed the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.
Indicates that the actor has created the object.
Indicates that the actor has deleted the object. This implies, but does not require, the permanent destruction of the object.
Indicates that the actor has delivered the object. For example, delivering a package.
Indicates that the actor has denied the object. For example, a manager may deny a travel request.
Indicates that the actor disagrees with the object.
Indicates that the actor dislikes the object. Note that the "dislike" verb is distinct from the "unlike" verb which connotates that the object had been previously "liked".

Indicates that the actor has experienced the object in some manner. Note that, depending on the specific object types used for both the actor and object, the meaning of this verb can overlap that of the "consume" and "play" verbs. For instance, a person might "experience" a movie; or "play" the movie; or "consume" the movie. The "experience" verb SHOULD be considered a more generic form of other more specific verbs as "consume", "play", "watch", "listen", and "read"
Indicates that the actor marked the object as an item of special interest.
Indicates that the actor has found the object. If a target is specified, it SHOULD indicate where the object was found.

Indicates that the actor began following the activity of the object. In most cases, the object will be a Person, but it can potentially be of any type that can sensibly generate activity. Processors MAY ignore (silently drop) successive identical "follow" activities.

Indicates that the actor is giving an object to the target. Examples include one person giving a badge object to another person. The object identifies the object being given. The target identifies the receiver.
Indicates that the actor is hosting the object. As in hosting an event, or hosting a service.
Indicates that the actor has ignored the object. For instance, this verb may be used when an actor has ignored a friend request, in which case the object may be the request-friend activity.
Indicates that the actor has inserted the object into the target.
Indicates that the actor has installed the object, as in installing an application.
Indicates that the actor has interacted with the object. For instance, when one person interacts with another.

Indicates that the actor has invited the object, typically a person object, to join or participate in the object described by the target. The target could, for instance, be an event, group or a service.

Indicates that the actor has become a member of the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is a group, though implementors SHOULD be prepared to handle other Object types as meaning MAY be provided by extension specifications. Processors MAY ignore (silently drop) successive identical "join" activities.
Indicates that the actor has left the object. For instance, a Person leaving a Group or checking-out of a Place.
Indicates that the actor marked the object as an item of special interest. The "like" verb is considered to be an alias of "favorite". The two verb are semantically identical.

Indicates that the actor has listened to the object. This is typically only applicable for objects representing audio content, such as music, and audio-book, or a radio broadcast. The "listen" verb is a more specific form of the "consume", "experience" and "play" verbs.
Indicates that the actor has lost the object. For instance, if a person loses a game.

Indicates the creation of a friendship that is reciprocated by the object. Since this verb implies an activity on the part of its object, processors MUST NOT accept activities with this verb unless they are able to verify through some external means that there is in fact a reciprocated connection. For example, a processor may have received a guarantee from a particular publisher that the publisher will only use this Verb in cases where a reciprocal relationship exists.
Indicates that the actor has opened the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.

Indicates that the actor spent some time enjoying the object. For example, if the object is a video this indicates that the subject watched all or part of the video. The "play" verb is a more specific form of the "consume" verb.
Indicates that the actor has presented the object. For instance, when a person gives a presentation at a conference.
Indicates that the actor has purchased the object. If a target is specified, in indicates the entity from which the object was purchased.
Indicates that the actor has qualified for the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the qualification applies.

Indicates that the actor read the object. This is typically only applicable for objects representing printed or written content, such as a book, a message or a comment. The "read" verb is a more specific form of the "consume", "experience" and "play" verbs.
Indicates that the actor is receiving an object. Examples include a person receiving a badge object. The object identifies the object being received.
Indicates that the actor has rejected the object.
Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the target.
Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of friends.
Indicates that the actor has replaced the target with the object.
Indicates that the actor has requested the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity from which the object is being requested.
Indicates the creation of a friendship that has not yet been reciprocated by the object.
Indicates that the actor has resolved the object. For instance, the object could represent a ticket being tracked in an issue management system.
Indicates that the actor has returned the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was returned.

Indicates that the actor has retracted the object. For instance, if an actor wishes to retract a previously published activity, the object would be the previously published activity that is being retracted.

The "possible RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a possible RSVP for the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event (see ), though implementors SHOULD be prepared to handle other object types as meaning MAY be provided by extension specifications. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

The "negative RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a negative RSVP for the object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event (see ), though implementors SHOULD be prepared to handle other object types as meaning MAY be provided by extension specifications. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

The "positive RSVP" verb indicates that the actor has made a positive RSVP for an object. This specification only defines the meaning of this verb when its object is an event (see ), though implementors SHOULD be prepared to handle other object types as meaning MAY be provided by extension specifications. The use of this verb is only appropriate when the RSVP was created by an explicit action by the actor. It is not appropriate to use this verb when a user has been added as an attendee by an event organiser or administrator.

Indicates that the actor has satisfied the object. If a target is specified, it indicate the context within which the object was satisfied. For instance, if a person satisfies the requirements for a particular challenge, the person is the actor; the requirement is the object; and the challenge is the target.

Indicates that the actor has called out the object as being of interest primarily to him- or herself. Though this action MAY be shared publicly, the implication is that the object has been saved primarily for the actor's own benefit rather than to show it to others as would be indicated by the "share" verb.
Indicates that the actor has scheduled the object. For instance, scheduling a meeting.
Indicates that the actor is or has searched for the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the search is or has been conducted.
Indicates that the actor has sold the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was sold.
Indicates that the actor has sent the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was sent.
Indicates that the actor has called out the object to readers. In most cases, the actor did not create the object being shared, but is instead drawing attention to it.

Indicates that the actor has sponsored the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the sponsorship is offered. For instance, a company can sponsor an event; or an individual can sponsor a project; etc.
Indicates that the actor has started the object. For instance, when a person starts a project.
Indicates that the actor has stopped following the object.
Indicates that the actor has submitted the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity to which the object was submitted.
Indicates that the actor has associated the object with the target. For example, if the actor specifies that a particular user appears in a photo. the object is the user and the target is the photo.
Indicates that the actor has terminated the object.
Indicates that the actor has neither won or lost the object. This verb is generally only applicable when the object represents some form of competition, such as a game.
Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of favorited items.
Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of liked items.

Indicates that the actor has not satisfied the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the context within which the object was not satisfied. For instance, if a person fails to satisfy the requirements of some particular challenge, the person is the actor; the requirement is the object and the challenge is the target.
Indicates that the actor has removed the object from the collection of saved items.
Indicates that the actor is no longer sharing the object. If a target is specified, it indicates the entity with whom the object is no longer being shared.

The "update" verb indicates that the actor has modified the object. Implementors SHOULD use verbs such as post where the actor is adding new items to a collection or similar. Update is reserved for modifications to existing objects or data such as changing a user's profile information.
Indicates that the actor has used the object in some manner.

Indicates that the actor has watched the object. This verb is typically applicable only when the object represents dynamic, visible content such as a movie, a television show or a public performance. This verb is a more specific form of the verbs "experience", "play" and "consume".
Indicates that the actor has won the object. This verb is typically applicable only when the object represents some form of competition, such as a game.

section.title: Alert
section.t: The "alert" object type indicates that the object represents a significant notification of any kind.

section.title: Application
section.t: The "application" object type represents a software application of any sort.

section.title: Article
section.t: The "article" object type indicates that the object is an article, such as a news article, a knowledge base entry, or other similar construct. Such objects generally consist of paragraphs of text, in some cases incorporating embedded media such as photos and inline hyperlinks to other resources.

section.title: Audio
section.t: The "audio" object type represents audio content.
At a minimum, an audio object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
An optional HTML fragment that, when embedded in an HTML page, will provide an interactive player UI for the audio stream.
Media Link
A link to the audio content itself. Represented in JSON as a media link as defined in JSON Activity Streams 1.0.

section.title: Badge
section.t: The "badge" object type represents a Badge or Award granted to an object (typically a person).

section.title: Binary
section.t: The "binary" object type is used to carry arbitrary Base64-encoded binary data within an Activity Stream object. It is primarily intended to attach binary data to other object types through the use of the "attachments" property.
At a minimum, the binary object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the object. If the object object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

A comma-separated list of compression algorithms applied to the binary data prior to Base64-encoding. Possible algorithms are "deflate" and "gzip", respectively indicating the use of the compression mechanisms defined by and . Additional compression algorithsm MAY be used. If multiple compression algorithms are applied, they must be listed in the order they were applied to the data. For instance, if the data was first compressed with deflate and then again using gzip, the value would be "compression":"deflate, gzip"
JSON String
The URL-Safe Base64-encoded representation of the binary data.
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the object.
JSON String
The IRI of the object described by this object.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the object.
JSON Number
The total number of unencoded, uncompressed octets contained within the "data" field represented as a non-negative integer value.
JSON String
An optional MD5 checksum calculated over the unencoded, uncompressed octets contained with the "data" field.
JSON String
The optional time the object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The MIME type of the object described by the object.
JSON String
The optional time the object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the object's HTML representation.

section.title: Bookmark
section.t: The "bookmark" object type represents a pointer to some URL -- typically a web page. In most cases, a bookmark is specific to a given user and contains metadata chosen by that user. Bookmark Objects are similar in principle to the concept of bookmarks or favorites in a web browser. A bookmark represents a pointer to the URL, not the URL or the associated resource itself.

When dealing with bookmarks it is important to note the distinction between the title, description, and URL of the bookmark itself and the title, content, and URL of the resource that is the target of the bookmark. In some implementations these MAY be the same, but bookmark managers often allow a user to edit the title and description of his or her own bookmarks to differ from the metadata on the target itself.
Some implementations refer to this object type as a "link". This specification uses the term "bookmark" to avoid confusion with the general concept of hyperlinks which apply to all object types.

Since bookmarks are often specific to a particular user, even though multiple users might have bookmarks pointing at the same resource, it is appropriate to use the post verb to describe the publication of such a bookmark. The favorite verb SHOULD be used when a user flags another user's bookmark as being a favorite without creating his own bookmark, or when a user flags his own bookmark as being a favorite as a special classification within his own bookmark collection.
At a minimum, a bookmark object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the bookmark. If the bookmark object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the bookmark as entered by the user who created it. HTML markup MUST NOT be included. Publishers MAY user the title of the target resource as a default for this peroperty where a user has not entered a customized value
JSON String
The unique identifier for the bookmark object.
Media Link
An optional link to an image resource providing a visual representation of the bookmarked resource. Processors MAY ignore thumbnails that are of an inappropriate size for their user interface.
JSON String
The optional time the bookmark object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The IRI of the item that is the target of the bookmark.
JSON String
The optional time the bookmark object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".

section.title: Collection
section.t: The "collection" object type represents a generic collection of objects of any type. This object type can be used, for instance, to represent a collection of files like a folder, a collection of photos like an album, and so forth.
At a minimum, the collection object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the collection. If the collection object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the collection.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the collection object.
Media Link
A link to an image resource that can be used as a preview image for the collection. Processors MAY ignore images that are of an inappropriate size for their user interface.
JSON Array of Strings
An optional array of JSON strings identifying the member object types for the collection.
JSON String
The optional time the collection object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the collection object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the collection's HTML representation.

section.t: Previous version of this specification defined specific object types for "folder", "photo-album", "playlist", and "list", each of which can be represented as "collection" objects with specific types of member objects, e.g. the "photo-album" can be represented as a "collection" of "image" objects. These more specific object types SHOULD be handled as deprecated aliases of the "collection" object type.

section.title: Comment
section.t: The "comment" object type represents a textual response to another object. The comment object type MUST NOT be used for other kinds of responses, such as video replies or reviews.
At a minimum, the comment object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the comment. If the comment object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

The main body content represented as a fragment of HTML. Publishers SHOULD include any markup necessary to achieve a similar presentation to that on the publisher's own HTML pages. Processors MAY remove all HTML markup and consider the comment to be plain text.
JSON String

The optional, natural-language, human-readable and plain-text subject of the comment. Many systems do not have the concept of a title or subject for a comment; such systems MUST omit the displayName property. Processors SHOULD refer to such comments as simply being "a comment", with appropriate localization, if they are to be described in a sentence.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the comment object.
JSON Array of Objects
A listing of one or more objects for which this object is a response.
JSON String
The optional time the comment object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the comment object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".

section.title: Device
section.t: The "device" object type represents a device of any sort.
At a minimum, the device object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the device.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the device object.
JSON String
The optional time the device object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the device object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the device's HTML representation.

section.title: Event
section.t: The "event" object type represents an event that occurs in a certain place during a particular interval of time.
At a minimum, the event object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Collection object
An optional link to a collection providing information about actors who have responded to the event object using the rsvp-yes verb.
Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the event. If the event object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the event.
JSON String
The date and time that the event ends represented as a JSON String conforming to the "date-time" production in
JSON String
The unique identifier for the event object.
Place object
The optional, location or venue for the event expressed as a place object as described in .
Collection object
An optional link to a collection providing information about actors who have responded to the event object using the rsvp-maybe verb.
Collection object
An optional link to a collection providing information about actors who have responded to the event object using the rsvp-no verb.
JSON String
The optional time the event object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The date and time that the event begins represented as a JSON String conforming to the "date-time" production in
JSON String
Optional short, natural-language, human-readable description of the event represented as a fragment of HTML.
JSON String
The optional time the event object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the event's HTML representation.

section.title: File
section.t: The "file" object type represents some document or other file with no additional machine-readable semantics.

It is intended that this type be used as a base type for other Objects that manifest as files, so that additional semantics can be added while providing a fallback ability for clients that do not support the more specific Object type.
At a minimum, the file object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the file. If the file object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the file.
JSON String
The IRI of the file described by this object.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the file object.
JSON String
The optional time the file object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The MIME type of the file described by the object.
JSON String
The optional time the file object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the file's HTML representation.

section.title: Game
section.t: The "game" object type represents a game or competition of any sort.
At a minimum, the game object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the game.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the game object.
JSON String
The optional time the game object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the game object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the game's HTML representation.

section.title: Group
section.t: The "group" object type represents a grouping of objects in which member objects can join or leave.
At a minimum, the group object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the group. If the group object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the group.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the group object.
JSON String
The optional time the group object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the group object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the group's HTML representation.

section.title: Image
section.t: The "image" object type represents a graphical image.
Previous versions of this specification had defined a "photo" object type which SHOULD be treated as a deprecated alias of "image".
At a minimum, the image object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the image. If the image object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
Optional natural-language and plain-text caption for the image. HTML Markup MUST NOT be used.
Media Link
A link to a thumbnail version of the image. Processors MAY ignore thumbnails that are of an inappropriate size for their user interface.
Media Link
A link to a larger -- ideally, full-size -- version of the image intended for standalone viewing.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the image object.
JSON String
The optional time the image object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
Optional, natural-language description of the image in the form of a fragment of HTML.
JSON String
The optional time the image object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the image's HTML representation.

section.title: Job
section.t: The "job" object type represents information about a job or a job posting.
At a minimum, the job object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the job.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the job object.
JSON String
The optional time the job object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the job object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the job's HTML representation.

section.title: Note
section.t: The "note" object type represents short-form text messages. This object type is intended for use in "micro-blogging" and in systems where users are invited to publish short, often plain-text messages whose useful lifespan is generally shorter than that of an article or weblog entry.

A note is similar in structure to an article, but it does not have a title and its body tends to be shorter. Applications will often display the entire content of a note in an activity stream UI, whereas they MAY display only the title or the title and summary for a weblog entry.
At a minimum, a note object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the note. If the note object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

The content of the note. Publishers SHOULD include any markup necessary to achieve a similar presentation to that on the publisher's own HTML pages, including any links that the service automatically adds. Processors MAY remove all HTML markup and consider the comment to be plain text.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the note object.
JSON String
The optional time the note object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the note object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the note's HTML representation.

section.t: It is expected that the "note" object type can be used for a broad range of purposes, including the representation of a human-readable description of what the author is doing, feeling or experiencing. Older versions of this specification had defined a "status" object type for that purpose. There are deployed implementations that currently still use "status". The "status" object type SHOULD be treated as a deprecated alias of the "note" object type. The determination of whether or not a "note" object represents a person's current status is based on the context in which the "note" is used.

section.title: Offer
section.t: The "offer" object type represents an offer of some form. For instance, an offer to sell a particular item.
At a minimum, the object object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Object
An Activity Streams object that provides information about the availability of the offer.
Object
An Activity Streams object that provides information about the condition of the item being offered.
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the offer.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the offer object.
Object
An Activity Streams object that provides information about the item or items being offered.
JSON String
The optional time the offer object was created in the form of an "date-time".
Object
An Activity Streams object that provides information about the relevant terms and restrictions on the offer.
JSON String
The optional time the offer object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the offer's HTML representation.
JSON String
The optional date and time at which the offer becomes valid specified as an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional date and time after which the offer is no longer valid specified as an "date-time".

section.title: Person
section.t: The "person" object type represents a user account. This is often represents a person, but might also be a company or fictitious character that is being represented by a user account.
At a minimum, the person object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
Media Link
A link to an image representing the person. Processors MAY ignore thumbnails that are of an inappropriate size for their user interface.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the person object.
JSON String
The optional time the person object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the person object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the person's HTML representation.

section.title: Place
section.t: The "place" object type represents a location on Earth. Locations can be represented using geographic coordinates, a physical address, a free-form location name, or any combination of these.
At a minimum, the place object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
An optional natural-language, human-readable and plain-text name of the place. HTML markup MUST NOT be included
JSON String
The unique identifier for the place object.
JSON String
The optional latitude, longitude and altitude of the place as a point on Earth. Represented as an ISO 6709 compliant string. For instance "position":"+27.5916+086.5640+8850/".
JSON Object
A optional physical address represented as a JSON object with the properties defined in the table below.
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the place's HTML representation.

section.t: The properties for the address property are:

texttable.c: JSON String
The full mailing address formatted for display or use with a mailing label.
JSON String
The street address including house number, street name, P.O. Box, and extended multi-line address information.
JSON String
The city or locality.
JSON String
The state or region.
JSON String
The zip or postal code.
JSON String
The country name component.

section.title: Process
section.t: The "process" object type represents a process of some sort.
At a minimum, the process object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title of the process.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the process object.
JSON String
The optional time the process object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the process object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the process' HTML representation.

section.title: Product
section.t: The "product" object type represents a commercial good or service.
At a minimum, the product object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the product. If the product object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
Optional natural-language and plain-text name for the product. HTML Markup MUST NOT be used.
Media Link
A link to a larger -- ideally, full-size -- version of the image of the product.
Media Link
A link to a thumbnail-sized image of the product. Processors MAY ignore thumbnails that are of an inappropriate size for their user interface.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the product object.
JSON String
The optional time the product object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
Optional, natural-language description of the product in the form of a fragment of HTML.
JSON String
The optional time the product object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the product's HTML representation.

section.title: Question
section.t: The "question" object type represents a question or poll.
At a minimum, a question object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the question. If the review object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

The content of the question in the form of a fragment of HTML. Publishers SHOULD include any markup necessary to achieve a similar presentation to that on the publisher's own HTML pages, including any links that the service automatically adds. Processors MAY remove all HTML markup and consider the content to be plain text.
JSON String

The title of the question. Some systems do not have the concept of a title for a question; such systems MUST omit the displayName property. Processors SHOULD refer to such questions as simply being "a question", with appropriate localization, if they are to be described in a sentence.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the question object.
JSON Array of Objects
An optional listing of possible answers for the question. These may be of any objectType and SHOULD contain an id property distinctly identifying each possible answer.
JSON String
The optional time the question object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The optional time the question object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the question's HTML representation.

section.title: Review
section.t: The "review" object type represents a primarily prose-based commentary on another object.
At a minimum, a review object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the review. If the review object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String

The content of the review in the form of a fragment of HTML. Publishers SHOULD include any markup necessary to achieve a similar presentation to that on the publisher's own HTML pages, including any links that the service automatically adds. Processors MAY remove all HTML markup and consider the content to be plain text.
JSON String

The title of the review. Many systems do not have the concept of a title for a review; such systems MUST omit the displayName property. Processors SHOULD refer to such reviews as simply being "a review", with appropriate localization, if they are to be described in a sentence.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the review object.
JSON String
The optional time the review object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON Number
A rating for the object given as a number between 1.0 and 5.0 inclusive with one decimal place of precision.
JSON String
The optional time the review object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the review's HTML representation.

section.title: Service
section.t: The "service" object type represents a website, personal website or blog, business, brand, or other entity that performs some kind of work for other entities, people, or services, or acts as kind of container for other objects.
At a minimum, the service object has the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, plain-text name of the service. HTML markup MUST NOT be used.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the service object.
Media Link
A link to a small image representing the service.
JSON String
The optional time the service object was created in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String

A description of the service in the form of a fragment of HTML. Publishers SHOULD include any markup necessary to achieve a similar presentation to that on the publisher's own HTML pages, including any links that the service automatically adds. Processors MAY remove all HTML markup and consider the content to be plain text.
JSON String
The optional time the service object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".
JSON String
The permanent IRI of the service's HTML representation.

section.title: Task
section.t: The "task" object type represents an activity that has yet to be completed.
At a minimum, the task object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Object
An optional Activity Streams object that provides information about the actor that is expected to complete the task.
JSON String
An optional "date-time" specifying the date and time by which the task is to be completed.
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title for the task.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the task object.
Object
An Activity Streams object describing the object of the task.
Array of Tasks
An optional Array of other "task" objects to be completed before this task can be completed.
JSON Boolean
A boolean value indicating whether completion of the task is considered to be mandatory or not.
Array of Tasks
An optional Array of other "task" objects superseded by this this task object.
JSON String
A String indicating the verb of this task.

section.title: Video
section.t: The "video" object type represents video content, which usually consists of a motion picture track and an audio track.
At a minimum, the video object has the following properties:

texttable.c: Activity Object

Activity Object, typically using the "person" object type, responsible for the creation of the video stream. If the video object appears within an activity, and the author is the actor for the activity, the author property MAY be omitted
JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text title for the video stream. HTML markup MUST NOT be included
JSON String
An optional HTML fragment that, when embedded in an HTML page, will provide an interactive player UI for the video stream.
JSON String
The unique identifier for the video object.
JSON String
The optional time the video object was created in the form of an "date-time".
Media Link
A link to the video content itself. Represented in JSON as a media link as defined in JSON Activity Streams 1.0.
JSON String
Optional short, natural-language, human-readable snippet or summary of the video stream represented as a fragment of HTML.
JSON String
The optional time the video object was last updated in the form of an "date-time".

section.title: Base Extension Properties
section.t: This specification defines an initial set of extension properties that can be used with all activities or objects.

section.title: Location
section.t: Location data can be added to any object type or activity. Location can be specified via geographic coordinates, a street address, a free-form location name or any combination of these.
Within a JSON-serialized Activity Stream, the Location is represented using a property named location whose value is a Place object. The objectType property of this object MAY be omitted.

When appearing within an activity, the location data indicates the location where the activity occurred. When appearing within an object, the location data indicates the location of that object at the time the activity occurred.
For example:

section.title: Mood
section.t: Mood describes the mood of the user when the activity was performed. This is usually collected via an extra field in the user interface used to perform the activity. For the purpose of this schema, a mood is a freeform, short mood keyword or phrase along with an optional mood icon image.
In JSON, Moods are included within an object or activity using a property named mood whose value is a JSON object with the following properties:

texttable.c: JSON String
The natural-language, human-readable and plain-text keyword or phrase describing the mood. HTML markup MUST NOT be included
Media Link
An optional image that provides a visual representation of the mood.

section.t: For example:

section.title: Rating
section.t: A rating given as a number between 1.0 and 5.0 inclusive with one decimal place of precision. Represented in JSON as a property called rating whose value is a JSON number giving the rating.
Ratings are generally most useful only for particular types of objects, such as audio, video, photos and places.
For example:

section.title: Source
section.t: The source property provides a reference to the original source of an object or activity. The value of the source property is an Object of any object type.

The source property is closely related to the generator and provider properties but serves the distinct purpose of identifying where the activity or object was originally published as opposed to identifying the applications that generated or published it.
For example:

section.title: Tags
section.t: A listing of the objects that have been associated with a particular object using the tag verb. Represented in JSON using a property named tags whose value is an Array of objects.
For example:
